variant.question: Consider a climb with a piston engine aeroplane. What will happen to the fuel flow if the pilot maintains the same power setting?

options.text: With increasing altitude air density decreases and the power output of the engine decreases. This has to be compensated for by an increased fuel flow.
The temperature decreases and thereby compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. Therefore the fuel flow remains the same.
The temperature decreases and thereby over-compensates for the decreasing air density which is caused by the decreasing pressure. This results in a decreasing fuel flow.
With increasing altitude air density decreases, therefore less fuel is required for combustion, so the fuel flow decreases.

variant.question: If a manifold pressure gauge consistently registers atmospheric pressure, the cause is probably:

options.text: leak in pressure gauge line.
ice in induction system.
fuel of too low volatility.
too high float level.

variant.question: If a manifold pressure gauge consistently registers atmospheric pressure, the cause is probably:

options.text: leak in pressure gauge line.
an aneroid capsule which is not properly calibrated.
a very high atmospheric pressure.
a very low atmospheric pressure.

variant.question: The `slipstream effect` of a propeller is most prominent at:

options.text: low airspeeds with high power setting.
high airspeeds with high power setting.
high airspeeds with low power setting.
low airspeeds with low power setting.
